div.bibl:
CHEAP REPOSITORY.
&rule;
HACKNEY COACHMAN;
OR,
The Way to get a good Fare.
To the Tune of “ I wi&slong;h I was a Fi&slong;herman,” &c.
46C1442 four-wheeled vehicle drawn by two animals
Sold byJ. MARSHALL,
(Printer to the CHEAP REPOSITORY for Religi–
ous and Moral Tracts) No. 17, Queen-Street,
Cheap&slong;ide, and No. 4, Aldermary Church-Yard,
and R.WHITE, Piccadilly, LONDON.
ByS. HAZARD, at Bath, and by all Book&slong;ellers,
New&slong;men, and Hawkers, in Town and Country.
Great Allowance will be made to Shopkeepers
and Hawkers.
PRICE ONE HALFPENNY.
Or, 2s. 3d. per 100 —1s. 3d. for 50 —9d. for 25.
[Entered at Stationers Hall.]

lg.head: I.
lg.l: I AM a bold Coachman and drive a good Hack,
With a coat of five capes that quite covers my back ;
And my wife keeps a &slong;au&slong;age-&slong;hop not many miles
From the narrowe&slong;t alley in all Broad St. Giles.
Tho; poor we ate hone&slong;t and very content,
We pay as we go for meat, drink, and for rent;
To work all the week I am able and willing,
I never get drunk, and I wa&slong;te not a &slong;hilling.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: What tho' at a tavern my gentleman tarries.

Why the coachman grows richer than he whom he
carries;
And I'd rather (&slong;ay I) &slong;ince it &slong;aves me from &slong;in,
Be the Driver without than the Toper within.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: For the dram-&slong;hop I hate and the dram-drinking friend,
Yet I'm not quite &slong;o good but I wi&slong;h I may mend;
I repent of my &slong;ins &slong;ince we all are deprav'd,
For a Coachman, I hold, has a &slong;oul to be &slong;av'd.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: When a riotous multitude fills up a &slong;heet,

And the greater part know not, boys, wherefore
they meet;
If I &slong;ee there is mi&slong;chief I never go there,
Let others get tip&slong;y, &slong;o I get my fare.

lg.head: VI.
lg.l: Now to church if I take &slong;ome good lady to pray,
It grieves me full &slong;ore to be kept quite away;
So I &slong;tep thro' the door-way, for here'tis the &slong;in,
To loiter without when one might enter in.

lg.head: VII.
lg.l: Then my gla&slong;&slong;es are whole, and my coach is &slong;o neat,
I am always the fir&slong;t to be call'd in the &slong;treet;
And I'm known by the name ('tis a name rather rare)
Of the Coachman that never a&slong;ks more than his fare.

lg.head: VIII.
lg.l:
Tho' my beads &slong;hould be dull yet I don't u&slong;e them
ill;
Tho' they &slong;tumble I &slong;wear not, nor cut them up hill;
For I firmly believe there's no charm in an oath
That can make a Nag trot when to walk he is loth.

lg.head: IX.
lg.l: And tho' I'm a Coachman, I'll freely confe&slong;s,
I beg of my Maker my labors to ble&slong;s;
I prai&slong;e him each morning, and pray every night,
And 'tis this makes my heart feel &slong;o cheerful and light.

lg.head: X.
lg.l: When I drive to a Fun'ral I care not for drink,
That is not the moment to guzzle, but think;

I wi&slong;h I cou'd add both of Coachman and
Ma&slong;ter,
And That both of us &slong;trove to amend a bit fa&slong;ter.

list.head: Price 1d. 1/2 each, or 6s. 9d. per 100 — 50 for 3s. 9d. 25 for 2s. 3d.
list.item: Watts's Hymns for Children, complete, with Prayers.

list.head:
PRICE ONE PENNY each,
4s. 6d. per 100 —5o for 2s. 6d. —25 for 1s. 6d.

A New Hi&slong;tory of a True Book, in Ver&slong;e.

p.hi: On the 1&slong;t of June, 1795, was publi&slong;hed,

div.p:
The Shepherd of Sali&slong;bury Plain, Part II.— The Beggarly
Boy.— Wild Robert, a Ballad.

Daniel in the Den of Lions.— The Good Mother's Legacy,
— Patient Joe, a Ballad.

Hints to all Ranks of People.— The Happy Waterman.—
The Riot, a Ballad. —The Plowboy's Dream, a Ballad.

Tom White, Part II.— Noah's Flood.— Dame Andrews, a
Ballad.

Harve&slong;t Home.— Two Farmers, Part I.— The Hone&slong;t Miller,
a Ballad.

The Parable of the Vineyard.— The Two Farmers, Part II.
— The Sorrows of Yamba, a Ballad.

The Troubles of Life.— Sorrowful Sam.— Merry Chri&slong;t–
mas, a Carol.

New Thoughts' on the New Year.— The Hi&slong;tory of Mary
Wood, the Hou&slong;emaid; —Robert aud and Richard, a Ballad.

The Touch&slong;tone; or, the Way to know a good Chri&slong;tian,
—The Apprentice turned Ma&slong;ter ; or, the Two Shoe–
makers, Part II.— The Story of Sinful Sally. Told by
her&slong;elf, a Ballad.

One&slong;imus; or, the Run-away Servant converted.— Idle Jack
Brown; or, the Two Shoemakers, Part III.— Shop–
keeper, Part I.

Conver&slong;ion of St. Paul.— Jack Brown in Pri&slong;on; or, the
Two Shoemakers. Part IV.—Shopkeeper, Part II.

The General Re&slong;urrection, Part I.— The Hi&slong;tory of Charles
Jones the Footman, written by Him&slong;elf.— The Hackney
Coachman; or, the Way to get a Good Fare, a Ballad.

Carrying Religion into the Common Bufine&slong;s of Life.—
The Cheap&slong;ide Apprentice.— The Election Song, a
Ballad.

Look at Home ; or, the Accu&slong;ers Accu&slong;ed. —The Game&slong;ter.
—Turn the Carpet; or, the Two Weavers, a Ballad.
